this professor, and class can be classified as just irritating.  Subject matter isn't too difficult, she gives out a fair share of A's and B's however lectures are so boring and madatory.  I became more infatuated with the words that she pronounces wrong than i did with macroeconomics.

The class turned out to be mostly discussion based. Most days we would not make it all the way through the planned power point lectures-but you had to know the material you aren't tested on the discussion. Multiple Choice sections on exams were very easy, the problems were difficult, but she was willing to help. She curves well, I went from B+ to A

(con't from the previous review)...on the final, she allows a 1 page index card of notes (which must be turned in with the exam). She curves the class at the end, individually using 2 of her methods (which she'll explain in class). Whichever method is beneficial to that certain student's grade, she'll use it. Good professor!

She has an accent, but is still very understandable. Her lectures pretty much summarizes the readings, so if you read, you're good for an A. Allows 6 (drop lowest) 'pop' quizzes (not really, my TA announced the dates) to be counted as up to 5% EXTRA CREDIT. Quizzes, midterms, & final are multiple choice. Really helpful to and care about students.
Sometimes pretty hard to understand. Her lectures were mostly pointless if you do the reading then you will be fine without having to go. The class was overall pretty easy though.

Lectures lacked organization and showed little preparation. Tests straight from book content. Lectures useless but attendance mandatory, still not hard to get an A if you read the book and go to class.

She explained concepts in a very awkward way...hard to understand. If you ready the book/take notes, you'll be fine. Sometimes lecture is helpful...but you really have to teach yourself from the textbook/study guide. Recitations are alright if you can understand the teacher (they're all Asian usually).

An extremely helpful and knowledgeable professor. The content and graphs can be difficult, but she is more than willing to meet with you and take questions during class to help you understand. The accent is not hard to understand as long as you are coherent during lecture. Wonderful and very helpful instructor.

Really?!?  WORST class ever. Way too much material gone over too quickly. Unnecessarily confusing choices for multiple choice answers.  Practically every question is a trick question, if there is a way to throw the wrong answer among the choices she will do it.  No relevant examples to make this class useful or relatable in any way.  Very hard.
BORING!!  Study. Prepare to be yelled at- she doesn't understand the concept of a microphone.
Lectures aren't mandatory, but if you have a hard time understanding foreigners, I do not advise this class.

Extremely boring lectures, a horrible joke of a textbook, and a mediocre study guide. This class was a waste of my time (as I suspect will be the case with every GEC). If you want to take economics, you should probably take H200 instead.

As long as you read the book and worked with the study guide the exams were fairly easy. She gives an amazing curve, in Econ200 an 85 ended up being an A. Also the accent exists, but isn't too  bad, if you go to lecture you can adapt.
Not necessary to go to lectures you will just fall asleep. You have two midterms and a final with a few bonus quizzes never any homework or papers. Overall a fairly easy class.
Lectures are almost worthless.
She was genuinely interested in students doing well. Although lectures weren't necessary, they were really helpful, and she was willing to answer questions via email.

Lectures are so boring! Actually she's very fair in grading, and she gives out extra credits points. So It is not that difficult to get an A in this class. Exams are not so difficult if you really study the textbook. Going to class is just wasting your time by listening to a lecture that will confuse you.

Going to lecture is a waste of time.  She is not organized when talking about topics so the lectures are confusing.  If you take her class you are better off reading the book, working on the study guide, and going to office hours for help.
Had her for H201 and H520. Great teacher, grades fairly

I hated this class. I took it at the same time as my friends, but they had different professors and did extremelyw ell. I didn't understand half the stuff she said. I think she knows a lot, but has trouble getting it out. Not an easy A!
The subject matter is fairly interesting, but she's so boring that I had lots of difficulty paying attention. An Easy A if you're willing to try, but she makes it difficult to...

Lectures were very boring, just read through powerpoints verbatim with a few example problems. Posts all notes online prior to class so going to lecture is not necessary. The chapter outlines and practice quizzes in the workbook more than prepared me for the exams, which were very easy. Quizzes in recitation are purely bonus points.

This class was horrible. I learned absolutely nothing. And the sad part is that I have an interest in Economics. I can tell you more about her personal history (moving from Iran to Sweden to Georgia to Ohio) than I can about Macro Econ!!! She's not overly hard, it's just very difficult to prep for exams since you haven't learned anything!

Accent is annoying to listen to, lectures werent neccessary. I ended up not going to them and just read the book which i understood better. Study guide was useless and didnt really help. However, the lowest grade you could get was a C- and the curve was pretty nice. If you do bad on the midterms and good on the final, your final is doubled.
horrible. Strong accent and difficult to understand.  Lectures are not helpful and exams are tough
Very, very nice and helpful, but she did not communicate the very well. Exams are difficult and it is hard to gauge what will be on them.

Lectures could be somewhat boring but she did seem to care that we understood.  Her accent really isn't that bad; I never had a problem understanding her and she understood that she had an accent and had no problem with us asking her to repeat herself.  The midterms and final weren't too difficult.  Read the book and use the handouts to study.
I wouldn't reccommend her.  She is too hard to understand and the lectures are boring.
easy class. skip the lecture, read her textbook regularly, do the multiple choice in study guide. Not hard to get an Ab
Tough material, but she is patient with her students.
Extremely difficult to understand due to Persian accent.  Some what difficult, and seemed distant to the students.  All TAs are Chinese.  WTF?!
Easy enough if you go to class and stay awake...

Don't Take Her. She makes what could be  semi-interesting subject not only boring but much more difficult than necessary.  Lectures are awful and no different then reading the text.  Midterms are near impossible however there is a decent curve. Basically much more work then Mumy's class! Take him
very good

Dr. Mirzaie was an ok professor she's somewhat hard to understand because she's from Iran. Her notes are generally pretty good to study, but the study guides that she gives for the tests have everything on them that you'll need to know. You can take just the final because she will double it if it's better than your midterms.
She is very nice and willing to help. The class is not easy but you can get a good grade. I recommend this professor.

Friendly and tries to help everyone in class but it is difficult to understand her in general. She is unclear; I ended up not going to lecture and reading the book myself because she confused me. Extra credit quizzes are nice, also you can drop the midterms and double the score of your final exam for your final grade.
Nice person, but a bit hard to understand. Ended up barely going to lectures, but if you read the text it isn't hard to get an A
No Comments
No Comments

summary_comment: Dr. Haab is an effective but sometimes dry instructor who clearly cares about his students' success, offering multiple ways to engage and support them, including anonymous feedback and office hours. His lectures are straightforward and easy to understand, though they can be monotonous, and he provides numerous examples that often appear on tests. Students who attend class regularly and put in consistent effort tend to perform well.

Ratings.comment: Dr. Haab is very smart and he wants to teach his students. He has some great stories and the material is not hard to learn. However, lectures get very boring and most times I didn't listen and still did well learning it on my own. Also, assignments and tests are easy to understand just can take a lot of time.

Super nice prof wants you to do well, good lecturer but I found it boring so I never paid attention and was able to do well. If you do bad on the homework go to TA office hours and you are guaranteed a good grade.

He expects a lot from his students, but as long as you go to class and even halfway attention, you shouldn't have a problem getting a good grade in this class. He can be a little scattered within his lectures, but he's good at clarifying subject matter if you get a little lost. He tells TONS of dad jokes, so be prepared!
Very clear and concise when it comes to lectures. The material isn't tough to understand and the book follows right along with the lectures if you are one of those people who like to read.
Dr. Haab really wants you to succeed and gives you an opportunity to give him anonymous feedback on his teaching style. Go to class, do the work and you'll be fine.

I was dreading this class, but Prof. Haab made it enjoyable. He is light-hearted and uses a lot of good examples to help everyone understand the material. He is also very helpful. I recommend going to class if you want a good grade.

Great prof, very fair. Gives many examples and is always willing to help. The tests are pretty easy IF you go to class. If you don't go... good luck reading the textbook. It's boring! You're much better off going and learning his examples b/c he uses examples from lecture on the tests.

Class was very straight forward and not terribly hard. You're grade will directly reflect how much time and effort you put into it. You just need to memorize alot of terms and concepts. Very fair teacher though and is willing to help you out.
No Comments

SEI.Subject: AEDECON
SEI.Class Name: Econometric Applications in Agribusiness and Applied Economics

summary_comment: Professor Eric Mbakop offers a highly manageable course with generous grading on homework and curved exam scores, making attendance optional for achieving top grades. The workload consists of five homework assignments (with the lowest score dropped), two midterms, and a final exam that is easier than the midterms. Students consistently recommend his teaching approach.

Ratings.comment:
Professor Eric Mbakop's class is very manageable. There are five homework assignments (lowest dropped), two midterms, and a final that's easier than the midterms. 
Homework is graded generously, and exam scores are curved. I barely attended lectures—studying the slides and doing the homework carefully was enough to get an A. 
Highly recommend!

summary_comment: Professor Rehbeck is generally considered unorganized and difficult to follow, with issues grading and providing clear feedback. While some students appreciate his willingness to help and make the course accessible, others find his lectures disorganized and his absence from classes due to health issues problematic. His teaching style is described as fast-paced and challenging, though he is noted for being approachable and offering extra credit opportunities.

Ratings.comment: Terrible professor in terms of grading criteria, organization, and teaching the material. He takes forever to grade assignments and doesn't know how to put weights for exams and projects into carmen so you don't know what your final grade is. He posts old exams but refuses to post an answer guide to them. Overall unorganized and condescending.

Prof Rehbeck is a great guy and good professor. I had him for 4001.02. He genuinely cares about helping students do their best. Willing to answer questions. Not always good at responding to emails. My class was flipped which I liked. Gives a top up to tests. The two projects are relatively easy. One downside is he missed class for health problems.

He is not so healthy at all, canceling classes because of dentist appointments, sore throat, headache, and back spasms that even kept him from walking to a computer. Skipped for 5 or even more classes (we have 2 classes each week) throughout the semester. The university should probably take attendance of professors.

All he does is post reading materials on Carmen. During the lecture, he always hands out quizzes or publishes some practice questions on tophat and starts chatting with students. He will answer the questions about the materials, but this is not an organized way to thoroughly go through the materials. Poor lecturer but not so tough on grading.

I took 4001.02 with Rehbeck and I was initially really worried about his class. However, he makes his own chapters out of the textbook he uses and makes them into 7-10 pages. As long as you read the chapters and listen in class and ask questions (which he is very open to), this class is easy to succeed in. Definitely not as bad as it sounds.
He likes to pick favorites.

Rehbeck does teach this course at an undergrad level & makes it pretty easy. If you want a traditional micro class, I recommend registering with a diff prof. We spent most of the semester on utility theory and preferences & did some optimization at the end of the course. He provided a lot of opportunities for extra credit. Cool and funny prof.

John's class is pretty difficult and fast paced, so it's really important that you take the time outside of class to learn the material, but he's super nice and always available to answer your questions! There's also a huge curve and extra credit opportunities, so it's not that hard to get a good grade!

John really wants his students to learn. He had us take a bunch of surveys on ourselves and how we learn. Be prepared to fight for your grade. He's very friendly and charismatic, and always returns a smile. Great guy. The class will be hard. Be prepared to look up some of the course material on your own time to understand.

Huge curves and extra credit opportunities. Tests are really hard but doable if you prepare for them. Always holds review sessions before exams. Could do with more practice problems or review materials though. You have to work in this class but a good grade is definitely possible. Very approachable outside of class too! Likes bubble tea

Professor Rehbeck is not a great lecturer. He's really tough. I passed but like it was really hard. I don't know why a prestigious institution like The Ohio State University would employ someone so obviously unsuited to the rigors of professorial education. However, he is pretty hot though and has an ass that won't quit. Solid 6 in Ohio.

Not just a terrible teacher, but a terrible individual. Don't even think about taking a class with this professor. I have no idea how they certified him to teach undergraduate students. He's very smart, but he doesn't know how to teach. His exams are impossible.

He doesn't realize how difficult of a professor he is. To get such minimal credit in the course, you need to do so much work. For attendance points, you have to submit a one page long question and answer, which equates to 0.2% of the total course points. He curves his test which average out to around 30%, but they are not enough. Unbelievably hard

A nice guy but horrible teacher. Will wreck your GPA, 35% averages on exams which are your only grades, extra credit was a joke. Has no understanding of what undergraduates are capable of. Just don't do it. You don't deserve this.

summary_comment: The professor is highly knowledgeable and effective in teaching, emphasizing the importance of attending lectures and taking detailed notes, which are crucial for both homework and exams. Lectures are dense and require active engagement, and while the exams are similar to homework questions, understanding the material thoroughly is essential for success. However, some students find his lectures challenging to follow and wish for more practice problems, though the class offers a significant curve at the end.

Ratings.comment: He knows his stuff. Smart professor that will teach. You will fail the class if you do not attend lecture. You have to. You HAVE to take good notes. These notes are what will help you with the hw and exam (the entire class grade). I usually rely on book to teach myself for other classes,can't with this one. Class notes are only way to do well.
Youll fail if you dont attend lectures, write everything he says down. Tests are pretty similar to homework questions and office hours are extremely helpful if you need help

Pretty good lectures and you need to show up every class period because he does not post any form of notes on carmen. 80% of your grade are exams so there is a small room for error. As long as you show up and are actively trying to learn the material you should get an A. I recommend him! Has an accent but easy to understand.

Yaron really is a good guy a little hard to understand sometimes as he goes into detail on some things that we don't end up using. Skipping Lecture is not an option as you will only be able to answer the HW if you have the notes and have a grasp on the content covered. One thing I wish he did was cover Exam/HW type problems instead of theoretical
6 homeworks (drops the lowest), and 3 exams (drops the lowest, can skip the final!). He gives pretty great lectures and explains concepts super well. Really enjoyed learning from him. Take his class!

It is a little hard to understand him, but go to class! Taking notes on what he writes on the board is imperative to succeeding. It will help with the HW, as well as the exams. Redo the HW and the exam practice problems to study. He drops the lowest exam as well as curves a little bit at the end.

Homework and exam questions are more complicated than what is covered in lecture. Drops the lowest of three exams. Tests are only about 20 questions long so little margin for error. Large curve, my 81 was a B+. Requires strong math skills. He is a decent lecturer but provides few practice questions to work with. Prepare to learn independently.

Horrible professor and horrible class. 3 exams, 6 homeworks. He drops the lowest exam. His lectures are almost pointless because he goes on and on about material that seems easy but exams/homeworks are much harder to understand. Good luck trying to get help. He is not willing to take time. This class is designed for a math whiz. Heavy curve at end!

This is a difficult class but I though Yaron taught it very well. You don't need the textbook as long as you attend class and take notes. If you take notes during class, the homework shouldn't be a problem. Homework is mostly (but not completely) a completion grade. He allows a full page (front and back) on exams and drops the lowest of 3 midterms

I thought he actually taught this class pretty clearly.  If you did the homework, you would get full credit for it regardless if you did it wrong.  The only real negative I have for him is that the tests were all multiple choice, and there were usually only 13-17 questions per test.  So not much room for error!

When people ask questions in class the way he responds is condescending sometimes or he replies in a way that can make students feel dumb. He skips important steps when explaining how to solve things too. I think 4001.01 shouldn't even be a course because you can't fully understand intermediate micro with out understanding the Calc behind it.

Yaron is a great professor who teaches the content well. He allows you to prepare one sheet of notes for each exam and there is a slight curve at the end, so take good notes and this class should be pretty easy.

Nice guy and a capable teacher, this class covers a lot of material so go to office hours if you aren't a math whiz. He is very helpful there. Two exam structure was stressful, as the final was half of the grade, though he decided to curve the grade. I'd recommend him.

I took this class because I was interested in learning more about micro theory and how different markets worked. Yaron explained things in great detail and he definitely knows his stuff. As long as you try hard to understand everything you'll do fine. And don't get behind in this class because it covers a lot of material fairly quick.

summary_comment: Professor Jafar Olimov is known for his rigorous approach, with exams comprising 90% of the final grade and no room for curve or extra credit. His lectures are fast-paced and often challenging to follow, especially for students who struggle with accents or quick handwriting, but many find the homeworks helpful for preparation. Students generally appreciate his teaching style and recommend the course, despite the demanding nature.

Ratings.comment: Doesn't excuse any absences - missed a quiz due to court and had to take my 2nd exam with horrible Covid symptoms. 3 exams make up 90% of the grade, so there's little wiggle room. Class was listed as in-person, but lectures were 95% asynchronous, which was a nasty shock to learn. Prof. Olimov seems like a decent guy, just not my type of professor.

Professor Olimov is likely the best professor to take 4001 with. His lectures are very fast paced and sometimes difficult to understand fully. Try not to get overwhelmed too much with the lectures because the exams are fully based on the HWs so just practice those. Overall, I though he was a great guy and I would recommend.

I would not recommend. Exams are worth 90% of the overall grade. No curve or extra credit, even though the averages are 77%. He does let you have a cheat sheet for the exams but then he asks confusing questions. His lectures are just him scribbling on a chalk board going way too fast.

His lectures are really hard to follow because he has an accent and writes on the chalkboard with bad handwriting. There are also no resources to study or practice besides the homeworks. The tests are almost identical to the HW and you get a cheat sheet for the tests making them doable. It is only grades on 3 tests basically so no room for error.

Jafar Olimov teaches applied economics. Expect math.
Overall great professor, and learning wasn't hard in his class.

Exams are 90% of the grade, 2 midterms and a final (nothing dropped). I took his online section, and regretted it. Apparently he is better to take in person. The online lectures were hard to get through all at once sometimes. The content is hard, but not impossible if you study and ask questions. He does not seem to care about his ratings.
Hey I look this guy.

I heavily recommend taking calc-based 4001 with Olimov, the calculus was very easy and I'm not good at math.

One warning is that there are 3 exams and each is worth 30% of your final grade. Fortunately, all questions on the exams were copied from his homeworks and he would only change the numbers so you can just memorize how to do the hws.

Jafar is one of those professors where you can tell that he knows his stuff but it just doesn't translate in an academic setting. His handwriting is difficult to read, and his explanations sometimes make zero sense at all. If you take this course, sit as close to the front as possible, take heavy notes, and get ready to do a lot outside of class.
Overall good professor and a content heavy course

Prof Olimov knows his stuff. That being said, not a great professor. His lectures are all over the place and hard to take notes on, even if the material isn't necessarily hard. As an econ minor, I'd recommend taking this class with any other prof if possible. If you get stuck with him, just prepare to do a lot of heavy lifting outside of lecture.

As an economics major, I would never ever take Professor Olimovs's class again. He is extremely fast, has no PowerPoint, and overall is just an uninspirational teacher. You can barely understand his accent, let alone his awful chalkboard handwriting.

He is a really good teacher. Lots of examples in his class. You shall pass the course easily as long as you understand examples in lecture. Although exams rate heavily, they are similar questions both to homework and lecture.

Exams are 90% of your grade. Homework and quizzes are the other 10%. He takes attendance every lecture, and missing enough will automatically fail you. No extra credit and no curving. The material is difficult, but all exam questions are slightly modified problems from lectures and quizzes.
Material is hard. take with someone else who is easy. Doesn't curve. no extra points. Takes attendance every class.

Absolutely not interested in student success and inaccessible outside of class. Also not accommodating to students with disabilities. Focuses on proofs when tests and homeworks are exclusively practical problems which a max of 5-10 mins of each lecture are devoted to. His exams are based on homeworks--only saving grace of this class.

This class is solely graded by exams, there are quizzes & homework but they're only one point so all the weight comes from exams. If you do badly on the first exam drop the class. The course topics are tough if you're not an econ major and Olimov goes SO fast... Def utilize the tutoring room but also just don't take this class if you don't need to.
So strict and never reply the email. Didn't drop the lowest score and you should get 100 or 96 every exam to get an A.
Attendance is optional, but make sure to attend lectures. Did not drop the lowest exam score.

Awesome professor. Optional attendance, 90% of grade is based on exams (two mid-terms and final but he drops the lowest one), but exams are relatively easy and straightforward. Most exams problems come from homework and he goes over them. Always accessible after class or during office hours. I ended up with an A without having to take the final.
Boring and plain. Doesn't curve.
Prof. Olimov's class takes a lot of time. HW's are very long and the material is very conceptual. I had to attend all lectures and read the textbook ahead of time before almost every class.

Kinda dry teacher who is super knowledgeable about Econ so he can explain things a little harder than you need to know. 3 tests, drops one the other 2 worth 90% of your grade. Gives a participation quiz before each test with questions directly from the test. 7 homeworks, which make up the questions on the tests

This professor is typically considered the best professor to take this class with but I would disagree. One person would get a 100% and he thought that meant the whole class was learning when that wasn't the case. He only cared about the top 10% and left everyone else behind. Tests are 90% of the grade and homework problems are easier than on test.

The class was very straightforward. 6 essays and a 20 minute presentation (plus attending/grading others' presentations). He only grades 3 essays and the other 3 get a 100 as long as you turn them in (but you don't know which will be graded). The essays he grades, he grades pretty harshly but that's canceled out by the ones he doesn't grade.

Dry as it can get but he knows that and tries to make it better. There are 3 exams each 25 questions. He drops the lowest one and the other 2 are worth 45% each. So you basically have to be perfect to get an A but the questions are basically the same as the HW or examples. I think this is a much easier A the other sections of the class.

Jafar was a good teacher and more than reasonable with grading. The grades for the course were 6 essays, a presentation, and attendance to other presentations. Attendance wasn't mandatory until presentations started.

Prof. Olimov is my favorite professor. Took him for ECON 2367.02 and ECON 4001.01. Writing class was easy A. 6 papers and 1 presentation at end. Optional attendance. Micro class same. Quizzes and HW are effort grades. Exams from HW and quiz questions. Pay attn. to lectures, study, and you will do well. 2/3 exams count towards grade.

Really boring lecturer but probably the best option for this course. Follows the textbook heavily so you can either buy the book or just attend class. There are three exams but two count towards 90% of your grade. 10% is homework and quizzes which are graded for completion not accuracy. Very hard to pay attention but overall not bad.

The content in this class is complex and overwhelming, but he definitely makes it doable by making the homework and exams fairly simple. Homework is graded for participation, homework answers are eventually posted online, and exam questions are based on the homework, so it is not very difficult to do well. Definitely recommend him for this class!

This class is hard no matter what. But getting an A is not impossible. Hes funny & nice but Dr. Olimov way of teaching is a little overwhelming, but just follow his way of solving psets. The biggest problem here is that his office hours are so minimize to only a few hours on only one day of the week. So hes not very accessible outside of class.

Professor Olimov is a cool guy. He definitely has spent time in Russia and his accent is a nice addition to class. He explains things well but the material is pretty conceptual and can be difficult at times. Overall a good professor. pretty funny guy too. He made some pretty comical jokes

Prof. Olimov is one of the best professors at osu. He honestly gives you every chance to succeed by dropping your lowest exam grade and grading homework based on effort not answers. My only complaint is sometimes he is kind of hard to understand and can write a little sloppy so you might want to sit in the front however, he draws graphs very well.

His class is a little bit hard to comprehensive but as long as you take some time to study it you will be fine. The homeworks point isnt depend on how much u got right. If you show your hardworking on the homework u will get full credits. Quiz questions are from exam only change the number and the exam is supper easy if u take some time to review

SEI.Class Name: Current Economic Issues in the United States

summary_comment: The professor is highly knowledgeable and effectively blends theoretical concepts, mathematical models, and empirical research, making the class both challenging and engaging. Students emphasize the importance of attending lectures regularly and dedicating significant time to homework, as the course is demanding but ultimately rewarding. Despite the difficulty, the grading curve is relatively generous, offering a path to success with focused effort.

Ratings.comment: As a graduating senior in economics this class was my final Econ class. The class was very difficult and you shouldn't expect to do great in the class if you don't go to lectures. The professor is extremely knowledgeable about the subject and does a great job of blending the teachings of theory, the models and math, and the empirical research.

One of the hardest yet most interesting classes I've taken. Going to class is vital or you'll be lost. Each homework set took at least 5 hours so don't wait til the last day. Dr. Weinberg is a genius, but his lectures were filled with typos which is a problem when there are so many equations. Lectures need more examples instead of reading slides.

The course is graded on weekly problem sets, a midterm, and a final. This course was the most difficult economics course I have taken, and your full attention is required to be successful in the class. Despite the difficulty of the course, the curve is quite generous. Be mindful of the course, attend lecture, and a decent grade is feasible.

summary_comment: Professor Thomas demonstrates a strong grasp of her subject matter but struggles with online teaching methods, often catching students off guard with pop quizzes. Her classes are challenging, particularly for those less comfortable with advanced calculus, though she is effective in explaining complex concepts. Students find the material demanding and require significant study time, but acknowledge her intelligence and dedication to the subject.

Ratings.comment: I took this class in the middle of the COVID pandemic. She had to teach fully online and she had no idea how to work a computer. She had pop quizzes and I couldnt sus out when they would be. I told her to stop pop quizzing us so we had a chance to fully prepare. She took the criticism well and alerted us of quizzes so shes not the absolute worst

Professor Thomas is smart, and she does a fairly good job of explaining everything; but with that said, her class is quite difficult. She gets into a lot of calculus, and it can be confusing. If you're comfortable with calc 2, will go to every lecture, and make this your top priority class, then go for it, because she is a very smart economist.
Not the easiest class in the world. Definitely requires a lot of studying.

Somewhat difficult class (especially the second midterm, holy god). Assigns 4 optional homeworks, only grades are 2 midterms and the final. Occasionally stumbles over her own words/graphs, but I'm usually able to make sense out of what she is saying once all is said and done. Sure, I've had better professors, but I've certainly had worse too.

summary_comment: Dr. Sathya is an effective teacher who makes extensive use of online resources, including class materials and practice tests that closely mirror the actual exams. She offers opportunities for extra credit and maintains a system of random attendance checks, though the class is generally manageable.

Ratings.comment: Dr. Sathya was a good teacher and made all the class materials and content available online. Reviewing the homework and quizzes will help with the test, as the are extremely similar (if not the same!). She does take attendance every class, but overall the class wasn't bad.

Quizzes and homework are beneficial for a good grade on the exams. She gives out extra credit and cares about her students.  Notes are always online. Quizzes are online and can even take multiple times to get a perfect great. Random attendance checks.

summary_comment: Professor Weinberg is a fair and kind instructor who emphasizes understanding through homework and exam preparation. While his lectures are dry, he injects humor that makes them more enjoyable. Students find his exams challenging and similar to the problem sets, requiring significant study effort, especially for those without a strong math background.

Ratings.comment: This definitely is not a blowoff class, but if you spend time making sure you understand the homework you should do pretty well on the exams. He is a very fair, kind professor. His lectures are dry but his jokes make them more enjoyable. Strongly recommend reading the book to gain a more well-rounded understanding of the topics discussed in class.

If you need to take econ4001, trust me, don't take with him, many professors' classes are easier. His exam only includes 3 questions, each worth 30-35, if you get wrong with one, then you are over. Other teachers' exams usually include 70% multiple-choice, and 30% large questions, which is much easier. PPT is messy and useless.
I did not go to the lecture a lot, but I went to his office hours when I was doing the problem sets. He was very helpful and very clear. Great professor.
Really great professor! Very helpful, very clear.

Weinberg is a pretty boring lecturer.  That being said, if you mildly take notes and then put in effort right before the tests, you should do alright.  Also, make sure to do VERY well on the homework assignments because those can save your grade.

Very good guy. Lectures are upbeat. The material is difficult though.  Has fair expectations. Midterms and final require a lot of studying and there was one problem on the final that we had never seen before.  This class requires a prior knowledge of math, which I did not half. Class is probably a lot easier with math background.

Weinburg is a great guy when you get to know him.He says some funny stuff during lecture but can be unclear at times and when it happens, just blurt out a question about it and he'll help you out.The stuff isnt that hard if you do the problem sets right and read the book.The tests are exactly like the problem sets.Visiting office hrs is a good idea

I really enjoyed his class.  He provides such clear, concise notes in class that reading the book is more of a hindrance than a help.  Quick response to emails, great personality, fair exams, and just the right amount of work.
He's as goofy as all hell.  The voice, the laugh, the crazy faces, the bowtie picture...  Good teacher though.  Explains things well.  The midterm was relatively easy.  The final sucked major ass.
Bruce is a good guy...i never took econ before this but ended up with a good grade.  study your notes and practice tests for the midterm and final and you'll be fine.
nice guy but 60% of the class grade is the final. Basically if you screw up on that you are screwed for the class.

He makes his class challenging but also goes out of his way to make sure the students get a deep understanding of the material. He's helpful and is, refreshingly for the econ dept, excited about teaching and economics in general. If you can get him for 501.02/501A, do it.
No Comments
Makes the course challenging, but teaches it well

He was born as a teacher, and he is also intelligent and knows the subject he teaches well; two things you can not find in a professor often; Teaching ability&interest and knowledge&intelligence. Ok it sound like four things but it realy is two.
Great professor, I really enjoyed this class.
Boring as hell....look at his website to see his cool bowtie
No Comments
No Comments

summary_comment: No comments available

The professor is widely regarded as one of the weaker instructors at OSU, known for confusing lecture slides that require significant self-study, an aggressive demeanor in office hours, and an unfair grading system with heavily weighted exams. Despite some positive attributes like being a nice person to interact with and providing well-organized lecture notes, many students found the class challenging due to the lack of conceptual explanations and the need to independently learn the material.

Ratings.comment: One of the worst ones here at OSU. Lecture slides were very confusing and I had to teach all the material to myself. He can come off aggressive in office hours, which made me a little nervous to ask him anything which didn't help at all. His weighting of the class is also unfair.

Unfair weighting of class. Exams are basically worth our entire grade. Very bad at explaining concepts and I basically had to learn all the content myself. He means well, but he sometimes can come off in a passive aggressive manner.

Professor Ye was helpful for the most part. His lecture notes were well organized but his lectures were more restatements rather than new, thought provoking ideas. His true or false on the exams are extremely difficult while the math is fairly simple. Very nice person to interact with should you choose to go to office hours.

Very smart, nice guy. Lectures were interesting but rarely focused on material we'd actually be tested on, you have to work through examples independently to learn anything. Exams were hard (60% avg), little impact from HW + attendance but the class had a heavy curve. Not bad for a weed out class but get ready to put in work

Class is extremely hard, not because the content is particularly difficult (students with other professors seem to find this class easy), but he doesnt show any of his work on the notes and you have to reverse engineer all of his solutions. Doesnt review concepts at all.

A lot of the material on the exams were not even covered in class. The class lectures were just him reading off the board and the powerpoint. He really never explained anything and he made this class so difficult. The averages for our midterm was 50% and overall, he just made the class too hard.

Honestly, I'm not sure why he makes the Econ 4001 harder than the other professors. He would give us 100% on the homework and then when we followed a similar format on the exam, we'd get a 0 on it. Given, he does curve the class by a considerable amount, but he doesn't explain his notes well enough.

Very organized, clear, and down-to-earth. Followed the book closely, so we didn't have to take notes, but could concentrate on understanding the material during lectures. Often punctuated the lecture with interesting, relevant new  research, and the occasional sharp question.
Very fair professor.  The tests aren't anything you haven't covered.  Do the work and you will be fine.  Very helpful at office hours or after class

I took 501.02, and I have to agree with the engineering major who posted on 6/11/10. This class isn't hard unless you are looking for the material to be spoonfed. Study your homework assignments and make sure to understand every concept on the slides. If you do that, there is no reason why you can't get at least a B+ or A-.

Tough class, you will have to teach yourself a lot, Prof. Ye is very willing to help students and really tries, but he is not good at conveying the information to the students if you have to take 501.02 theres a good chance you will have him and best I can say is study the book and attend class because he gives points for attendance

as an engineer i'm used to having unclear, undecipherable lectures and teaching myself the material. this class was easy compared to my others, ppl are just ****in about not being spoonfed the material.

A nice guy who genuinely wants his students to do well, but Prof. Ye really isn't very good at imparting concepts. The material wasn't particularly difficult, but the lecture style causes a lot of people to struggle. If you're a decent student you shouldn't have much trouble. Otherwise, you may want to think twice about this one.

Took 501.02, I got a B. I bought the book and taught myself mostly. I went to the TA every single week for an hour. Lixin is the WORST TEACHER EVER.  He made the class a lot harder than it needed to be. Crazy questions on the exams. Didn't learn much. I would change majors so I never had to have him again!
interesting but hard

Highly recommended if you are looking for an excuse to kill yourself.  You can't understand anything the man says.  There is one midterm and one final exam, both impossible, never have an average over 50%.  The material isn't even that hard... he just makes this class so much harder than it needs to be.  Makes you feel stupid, even if you have a4.0

his accent is very thick and it's hard to understand him sometimes. soft spoken, so sit in the front couple rows if you want to hear anything. midterm was hard as hell, final wasn't that bad. VERY generous with the final grades, so don't sweat the hws and mid that much. exs come straight from the book. don't rush through the hw, understand them

Professor Li knows his stuff well, but simply does not know how to impart it to students. Half the class is asleep. Lecture's boring as hell, slept a lot in class. Finals and mids slightly difficult.6 assignments for the quarter. Reads from the slide. Gives no examples outside of textbook, not even to explain a concept. Stay away.

This is a difficult class, but it isn't impossible to get a good grade. Keep up with the book, notes, and go to class. Understanding the HW is really important. He is a nice guy and the lectures are fairly clear if you understand what is going on. Exams are similar to HW, though a little more difficult. He and the TA are usually willing to help.

Nice guy but his class is hard to understand and very boring.  Overall if you do the homework you will do well in the exams and the class shouldn´t be to hard. Also he gives a lot of opportunities to improve if you do not do well in the first half of the class.
Very soft voice, pretty tough grader but did teach the material fairly well. Would see who else was teaching the course but wouldnt say to absolutely stay away from him

Good professor! Sit up front to hear well because he has a soft voice.  Very good at explaining things in more than one way so that everyone can understand.  Problem Sets about every other week.  Semi-difficult exams.  Overall good prof and class.
No Comments
No Comments

summary_comment: Audrey Light is widely regarded as a challenging and ineffective instructor, with students describing her lectures as tedious and irrelevant to the exams. Many commenters found her exams exceptionally difficult and felt that she does little to assist students, often making their academic experience miserable. Students strongly advise against taking her classes.

Ratings.comment: Audrey Light is straight up poverty. Hours upon hours of mind numbing lecture videos and problem sets that have nothing to do with the exams. She might as well write the exams in a different language. I don't know who hurt her, but someone did and she wants to take that out on her students by making their lives as miserable as possible. The worst.

Rudest person I've ever met inside or outside of a classroom. She seems extremely unhappy and to genuinely hate people. I actually feel sorry for her in that she's so unhappy. I blame the university for accepting tuition money from students and subjecting them to a woman who obviously needs professional psychiatric help.

I do not know how Light is still a professor at this university. I have never left a RMP review before but she, even though I took this online asynchronously, still managed to be the worst professor I have ever had. Rude in emails + impossible midterm and final. The quizzes she gives are NOTHING like the exams. Please take a different professor.

I’m currently taking her course and was expected to “skip” the midterm because of health issues explained to her. She said there is no extension or makeup allowed, instead I’m expected to take the final which would count for 80% of my grade and cover the midterm and final exam. never experienced this with a professor before.

Very tough Professor, made me hate economics. So much so that I changed my major. She should not be allowed to be teaching. Does not help you at all, exams are ridiculously though. Does not post PowerPoint because "it does not help", rather makes us watch 1 hour long video. Videos where you are on the verge to fall asleep. DO NOT TAKE HER CLASS!!!

Took ECON 4001.01 asynchronously with Professor Light. I read the textbook and took notes, but didn't watch any of the lectures. The midterm average was around a 60%, but I personally found it straightforward. Would probably be a lot harder if it wasn't all multiple choice! Grade was determined by 10 quizzes, a midterm, and the final (50%).

No friggin clue how in the world I got a B. Sooo hard! Other profs teach the same class and its fine. Her class is dreadful. She wants you to buy the textbook which doesn't help at all. She doesn't teach ANYTHING and is sinfully boring. I learned absolutely nothing because she just talks and talks and talks while the only grades are exams.

Throughout my time at OSU, never left a single review. But after her class, I felt like I owed an honest review. I have always been a 3.7/3.8 student and a LOVER of econ. Her class made me hate econ. Her class & exams are ridiculously tough so one advice: DON'T TAKE HER CLASS UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCE, you & your GPA will regret it. Just like I am rn.

Professor light was one of the rudest professors Ive ever had. Most of the class had failed the midterm and the final. Throughout the semester she would send emails with very derogatory comments to her students. She was not in any way motivating or welcoming to her students. This class made me second guess pursuing economics.
why are all other professors for this course simple and she is terribly hard

For accounting, econ 4001.01 is a requirement. I saw the class listed as online and was like "cool, least I don't gotta go to Columbus." But Light says: Nah bro, you go to Columbus to take the exams!". I took a quick look at all the practice exams and they are really hard. She says quizzes aren't gonna be on exams as well. Just horrible and pitiful

Exams were impossible. Avoid at all costs if you can. She tells you the exams will structurally look like the practice exams, which they did, but maybe one or two questions were carried over from previous practice exams, so be ready for curveballs on the exam. Impossible course to get an A in.

This class was by far the most difficult course I've taken at OSU. Prof. Light was extremely unhelpful and disrespectful to her students. Instead of offering help to struggling students, she  blamed them for doing poorly and not being prepared enough. Her entire class rides on a few grades. My only hope is that she will read this and reevaluate.

Dont take this class. She is an awful professor that builds her ego creating overly complicated lectures and tests. She belittles her students over email in a very unappealing manner. She also puts 80% of the grade into 25 MC and 7 short answer which means each wrong answer is a critical hit to the your grade.

So many people gave Audrey such a bad review but in all honesty, she's not that bad. It's true that her video lectures are boring and the tests are quite challenging, but she lays everything out clearly and if you do the problem sets and study Q's then you should be fine. Also, there is a curve!

By far the worst teacher and hardest class I've taken at OSU. Online lectures are tediously boring with her monotone voice. Expects you to memorize 7 chapters of detailed information for exams. No formula sheet on exams. Grades unnecessarily hard on the open-ended questions on exams. Should not be teaching at a respected university.

Out of everything she could have done to make an economics class more relevant to her students, she chose to record herself in the banalest and uninterested monotone. You see this attitude when you talk to her and in her exams too. Poorly structured and lack of instructions. If you're not interested, do us both a favor and don't teach.

This is a very difficult class. The midterm was different from the problem sets and study questions we were given. When sending the email about the  midterm grades, she made it apparent that she will not be giving a curve at all. I would not recommend taking this class at all.

Audrey has to be the absolute worst economics professor I have ever had. Never have I encountered a professor so ridged and difficult. The midterm mean score pathetically hovered around a D. When posting grades, she clearly stated that no curve was to be allocated and to just drop the course if you did poorly. Simply put, this class is ridiculous.
Very very tough class, exam is nothing like the practice problems or weekly quizzes!!! Do not recommend taking her course, avoid her at all costs

She is the worst professor I have ever seen. Lectures are stupid and long but has no connection with exams. The average for the first midterm was only 68%. If you are going to take Econ 4001 don't choose her!!!!
Just awful. Won't take hers if I could choose again. Worst decision ever.

Have to say this class will give me the one and only B that I will ever get and drag down my GPA. I can't see why it is not because of the teacher or the way she teaches. Extremely LONG online lectures that dull you to death, not helpful at all practice problems and negative attitudes, I am just speechless regarding this class.

Awful. Worst professor I've ever had. Most people failed the first midterm. When asked for extra practice problems she said she didn't have time to upload any. Extremely belittling toward her students. Refuses to do anything to help. Do not take. She does not deserve to be a professor at this university.
awful

Class starts slowly, but gets better as it goes. She is genuinely interested and has no problem with debate during the lesson. No essays, two midterms, 6 problem sets of moderate difficulty.  You will learn econ, and it could be a lot worse!

summary_comment: Bill White is highly regarded as an exceptional lecturer, known for making complex economic concepts engaging and relatable through practical examples. Students appreciate his availability during office hours and his willingness to help, though some find the mandatory attendance policy somewhat rigid. His teaching style is praised for clarity and effectiveness, leading to generous grading curves and high satisfaction among students.

Ratings.comment: Bill White is an excellent professor, while attendance is not mandatory he does occasionally call on students during the lecture which goes into an attendance grade. Overall he is a great lecturer who uses many real life relatable examples. Going to office hours helps a lot.

Very strong lecturer, makes it very attributable to future careers. Had open note exams until the final after he caught people cheating and made it closed note, understandable. Mix of econ people and glenn people, this class is easy for econ and probably more challenging for PPE. An interesting and applicable class
Interesting lectures with lots of examples. Concepts were explained clearly, exams were fair and not much homework. He cares a lot about his students.

Professor White is truly the best professor I've had for any Econ courses.  The man brings passion to his class every time he lectures, and he makes what would be mundane material very engaging and interesting.  I highly encourage taking his classes.

Econ is hard regardless of the instructor, but he was very willing to help and spend significant class time answering our questions. He let us have notes on the exams and pop quizzes. He was funny and real with us, and also very available during office hours to clarify material.

Best professor in the whole department by far. Explains boring concepts so well, and is always willing to talk out any questions you may have. Grades by participation, and end grade is curved by that participation. Couple of quizzes and homeworks, and three exams. Overall, a great guy and put in some effort in the class and an A is guaranteed.

If you are looking for an easy ECON course, take one with Bill White. His lectures are interesting, and he explains concepts very well. He doesn't require in depth economic principles or mathematics. He covers the basics very well and its very clear and easy to understand. He gives very generous curves, anyone who tried gets an A or B. Take him!

Great teacher, explains difficult topics really well. Randomly calls on students in class for attendance which is kinda beat but lectures aren't terribly boring. He's also pretty sarcastic which can be fun

Great professor, taught me all I need to know about basic economics. Very easygoing and fun person, he made lectures interesting if you attended. I did say that the class requires a textbook, but all it needs is Freakonomics, which is easy to find online!

Intro to economics with Bill White was incredibly easy. The material is not very stimulating, but White is a very nice guy and an easy grader. I didn't turn in the first homework (out of 100 points) and I still finished the class with a 95%. Once you get to the essay assignments, you practically get 100% for answering the question.

His grade evaluation was very unfair. At the same time, he randomly grouped the class, if you have good teammates, you can get an A without studying. But my teammates were not that good, resulting in such a low score. He never listens to your explanations

Bill is the real deal. He knows his stuff with real world experience and cares about his students doing well. He gives a generous amount of extra credit with pop quizzes being extra 5% plus a curve at the end. He is very helpful when you ask questions, and as long as you actually go to class and do the reading it's not too hard at all.
85% of the grade was 3 tests and all of those tests were impossible. the lectures are hard to sit through but he does actually care about what hes doing

Professor White's Underground Economy class is not particularly difficult. All that he asks is that you participate twice in class discussions, and attend the presentations. The pacing is a little fast at first, but once you get the presentations, it's a cake walk. And if you like writing, then it's even easier.

Dr. Whites lectures are not very stimulating, but he does talk fast and shares fun stories. Overall, hes a good guy and will help and encourage you. The final was worth 30% of the grade and the midterms worth 20% each. The final research paper was 10% of the grade, so the homeworks dont really help your grade. You will get an A or B in this clas

BILL! An absolute legend. Teaches by real-world example, not hypotheticals. Lectures can drag on a bit but if you zone out for a hot sec, you won't miss much. Very sweet man who is willing to help and happy to answer questions. Didn't read the book much except for exams! Had two online midterms and one online final, easy A if you pay attention.

I had professor White for underground Econ and let me tell you do not ever take this class with Bill White. Almost the entire course is based off of group projects so if you have a bad group you're screwed because you're with the same group the whole semester. Bill is a tough and borderline unfair grader I would avoid this guy at all costs.v

Coming from Dr Hartman's micro econ to Dr White's macro econ was a big switch. It's a lot different and tougher. Dr White's lectures are boring, but they are essential to understanding material. You will need to review those before every test, they're on Carmen. His tests were relatively difficult in my opinion, but you can pull a B if you study.

Honestly one of the best professors I've had. He explains the material very well and gives tonnnns of extra credit. If you get an 88 or higher you get an A. Everything was reasonable for the midterms, however, the final screwed me over and took my grade to a B so beware of that.
Very nice instructor

Bill was accessible and gave excellent lectures. He was attentive and respectful of every students lectures, even the questions asked by the brain-dead fisher crowd.   Class is entirely optional but pop-quizes are a great way to get extra credit.

His lectures can get boring, but being there in class really helps you out on the tests. He does post all the lecture notes online. There are pop quizzes beware!  Although the material might not necessarily be interesting, his passion and interest in the topic is enough to keep me going. He is a good guy!

summary_comment: Professor Dadzie shows up consistently and maintains a straightforward class structure, focusing heavily on quizzes and exams where he provides detailed answer explanations. While some students found his approach effective and appreciated his willingness to help, others struggled with the material and found his lectures and organization lacking, deeming him one of the worst professors they had encountered.

Ratings.comment: Professor Dadzie was a good professor! Showing up to class is necessary as he never really used Canvas much, but the layout of the class was simple. Most grades were from quizzes and exams but he literally goes over the exact answers in class and answered questions generously. He also always emailed me back quickly too.

I've had Dadzie for a lot of classes within the EEDS major. As long as you pay attention and do the work, his grading is valid. Make sure you pay attention during lecture, and if you have questions- ask. He is willing to explain and often gives you the main points you need to know before any exam. Just show up to class and you should be fine!

A pretty basic subject was turned impossible by Dadzie. The "quizzes" were essentially midterms, so prepare hard for them. He is impossible to work with, unorganized, didn't use Carmen, and one of the worst professors I've ever had. I hope they get some new professors to teach his material because he was the only prof available for this class.

Cool professor, really knows his stuff & tried to make the class engaging. The lectures were boring, but it was more-so because of the material. Quizzes were pretty easy, some pop quizzes counted as extra credit. The group project/debate were okay. Overall, really nice guy; the class was not too hard, just boring. Don't bother buying the textbook

summary_comment: Puabli's lectures are generally engaging but her grading system can be unfavorable and inconsistent, often returning assignments late. Despite this, she excels at explaining concepts clearly and thoroughly, making her a highly effective teacher when it comes to recitation sessions.

Ratings.comment: Puabli's lectures can be interesting and engaging. Part of her grading system can be a little unfavorable to the student, especially with the quizzes you have to take. Her grading on assignments is inconsistent and is returned in an untimely manner. Overall, the class was somewhat interesting but if you can take a different elective, you should.

I had Pubali as a recitation instructor, but she was so amazing she deserves a review! She explains concepts perfectly and has no issue slowing down to explain basics from the ground up. Pubali is a wonderful teacher!

summary_comment: Kerry is highly regarded as a knowledgeable and likable professor who provides clear lectures and is willing to help students. His classes are generally easy to manage with straightforward exams, though some students find the material covered in class differs significantly from the exams. Overall, Kerry is considered one of the better instructors at Ohio State, with a reputation for being approachable and responsive to student inquiries.

Ratings.comment: I wrote a review when I took him last year when I looked back when rating my professors this year it had vanished. I have a feeling he reported it but I can't see why it was taken down because it's not like I said anything bad. The final grade is determined by 3 exams which do not look anything like what you learn in class.
Great professor, provides the notes, interesting lectures, straight forward exams. Always willing to help his students, even provides review for every exam.
One of the better instructors at Ohio State.  I recommend taking any of his classes.

Kerry is very helpful and more than willing to re-explain topics if needed; however, he usually has very short and direct slides that don't require much explanation.  This is my second class with him and both were easy as long as you just pay attention and read the slides.  No need for many notes. Highly recommend taking.

Class was Cake.  No textbook. lecture slides were online.  Everything came from that so really no need to go to class, except it is attendance based, which is the only bad part.  Really into what he does, explains stuff great, approachable, laid back really a good teacher.  Next quarter he is teaching Sport Economics then he is done teaching at OSU

Kerry is a very knowledgeable and likable teacher. If you go to class and study for the midterms his class is very manageable. He is quick to respond to student emails and has a casual yet informative learning environment. One of the best teachers I have had at OSU
3 Midterms, 3 one page papers, and attendance. I could have got an A, but I missed too many classes. The material was interesting and easy to comprehend. Kerry is a nice guy, very like-able.

The class is extremely easy, but Kerry is useless. Reads word-for-word the slides made by the textbook company for two hours each class. Bring a laptop, ipod, or pillow, you will need it. Ps he is NOT hot at all.

Kerry is a very good teacher. He tries to to relate all of the material to real life examples. Class does not involve a lot of out of class time. You have weekly homework assignments that take around 30 min to an hour. You only have one midterm and one final which is basically a midterm because it only covers second half of class. Take his class!
sooo helpful
He is OK, the only problem is that he gets lost sometimes.His exams are kind of harder than expected.Overall he is a good teacher.

Although I never went to class bc I found this stuff quite easy, Tan is a great teacher. He tries to make modern examples to help people understand economic theories. If you can understand economics and do the work, this class is a breeze just bc the professor is so good and so helpful. Very accessible via email.

Not being an econ major, I found this class rather difficult. I never went to class b/c it consisted of reading off of the powerpoint. The movie shown was on Google Video, so I didn't go to that either. Alot of cramming went into this class & I didn't learn much. Kerry is very resourceful and always helped if I needed it.
Taught from the book/slides that he posts on the web. Attendance def not mandatory. Kerry is very accessible via email, always replied back with answer usually within minutes.

Kerry is a good teacher. He is a grad-student, so he understands what it's like to still be in school (unlike some other professors I've had). 584 is a sweet class, and is def. not difficult. 3 exams and in class "quizzes" which area attendance grades. Great Class, and cool teacher.

Great Teacher.  He was a second year grad student when I had him and it was his first quarter teaching a course and it was an upper level course.  He did confuse himself from time to time but other than that he did a great job.

Kerry is the best TA for Econ that you will ever have.  A great guy, very funny and easy to understand. He makes the pretty boring subject of economics interesting and not too hard.  He will go out of his way to help you and if you email him with a question he will reply literally within 10 or 15 minutes.  I hope he will get to teach soon.

Kerry is a TA, however, he is better at teaching than some Econ teachers.  He is easy to understand, makes the quite boring and difficult subject of Economics a lot of fun.  He uses real life easy examples and helps you as much as he can.  You can email him with a question and he will respond in about 10 minutes.  Basically the best Econ TA.

summary_comment: Dr. Brown is highly regarded as one of the best professors at OSU, known for her expertise and patient, kind demeanor both inside and outside the classroom. She emphasizes thorough preparation through homework, and her classes are particularly recommended for economics majors due to her clear explanations and supportive approach.

Ratings.comment: Dr. Brown is one of the best professors I have had at OSU. She is very good at this field and so patient and kind in and out of the class. If you do all the homework, you will be fine. There's a group presentation at the end of the semester. Please consider choosing her class, especially if you are an economics major.

summary_comment: This professor is widely regarded as subpar, with multiple students describing him as unhelpful, irrelevant, and disrespectful. Many complain about his tangential lectures, lack of accommodation for students with disabilities, and inappropriate comments. While a few found his lectures mildly entertaining, the overall consensus is that his teaching quality is poor and the class experience is generally negative.

Ratings.comment: Take this class with another professor. Worst class of my life.

Never talked about anything relevant to the class. Often talked of alcohol, drugs, partying, sex, and China??? Often made remarks to foreign TA that were not appropriate at all. He clearly had tenure and could not care less about his students actually learning anything.

TAKE REGULAR ECON, NOT AED. Openly bashed students who have testing accommodations (SLDS). Goes on weird tangents during class. Every exam was pushed back bc he was so behind. Racist towards our asian TA. One day he just didn't show up bc he forgot. Don't bother buying the textbook. This is a "teach it yourself"

Mark is horrible. Racist and chauvinistic comments made to TA and in general. Does not accommodate for SLDS students, and makes snide comments about them. Is late to class consistently. As an SLDS student myself, he refused to accommodate me in a time of need, and told me I would probably fail his class. An awful human that should be fired.

This professor went on tangents, sometimes completely unrelated to class. He does not accommodate students, particularly with SLDS. Be prepared to not only find other sources to teach you, but sit through problematic rants if you attend lecture for the random bonus quizzes.
Hilarious professor decently entertaining when he said things that only tenured professors can say

One of the worst lecturers on campus. He goes off on erronious rants constantly and moves through basic economic definitions at a turtles pace. Makes up for having pretty straightforward exams as well as in class extra credit participation points. The class is 95% exam based with one drop over 4 exams. Overall not a bad class just prof is not good.

Mark is such a good professor. If you pay attention during lectures you can get a guaranteed B or C. Attendance isnt mandatory but he offers a lot of bonus points during class, so its an incentive to go. I really like his lectures and he helped me in other ECON classes. Amazing guy and professor!

He made no changes to his syllabus to reflect COVID-19 and the hardships that come with it. 95% of your grade is exams, during a pandemic, mental health, and financial crisis. Was not very accomodating and rambles so it is hard to follow him as he teaches. This is a course you definitely teach yourself.

Bonus quizzes offered in class, so attendance is not required, but does help your grade. Take 4 exams (including final) and drop the lowest so it is a pretty easy A. He also clearly loves teaching and tries to have fun with it so that makes econ a little less awful
This guy managed to make what should have been a boring class very interesting. Attendance points count as extra credit on tests and you get to drop one exam grade. He's also hilarious.

I found his lectures to be very boring and hard to sit through for 80 minutes. It could just be economics but he also wasn't very engaging. He did give bonus points pretty much every week so I never skipped a lecture because then I didn't have to worry about the midterms. I ended up with a 108% as my final grade.
Excellent professor, he know's what he's talking about and does a great job of conveying that information to students.

Econ definitely isn't my thing, but Partridge wasn't a bad teacher. He allows bonus quizzes almost every lecture which he'll add to the exam. His class was a challenge for me and ended up with a B-, but half of that is because I had to miss one of the exams, and had to take the final which there isn't as much bonus for the final

Mark is AWESOME! He seriously is one of the sweetest professors I've ever had, and I love the way he teaches economics. Very understandable and relatable. Even friends who had him from semesters ago rave about him. Tests and homework aren't easy, but bonus quizzes should help make for an easy A in the class if you attend lecture and try.

If you take this AEDECON 531, be prepared to work your butt off. You HAVE to read the book & you should have some background in Economics; I didn't & I struggled. There are only 3 homework assignments, but they are hard. The midterm is all essay and the final is take-home, but 25 LONG essays. Class was boring and long, and he just read the slides.
Enjoyable conversational style lectures. Very interesting and applicable topics. Reccommended.

Mark is a great teacher. He has a Canadian accent and is always making up jokes. Attendance is not mandatory but he gives bonus points for attending.  His tests are tough but he usually curves it so most people have A's. He's not bad to look at either!

Economics isnt my thing but with this guy I went to class every day. He's crazy and really fun to listen to and the guy definetly loves his job. He reviews the previous days material at the beginning of class and explains thing very thoroughly! Take this class if you want an easy A and an interesting time!

SEI.Subject: AEDECON
SEI.Class Name: Principles of Food and Resource Economics

SEI.Class Name: Principles of Food and Resource Economics

SEI.Class Name: Principles of Food and Resource Economics

SEI.Class Name: Principles of Food and Resource Economics

summary_comment: Professor Kim, a PhD student, delivers lengthy and often unengaging lectures and employs a relative grading system that is not transparent. While the class offers an easy A and includes some extra credit, the lack of meaningful discussion and frequent mistakes on homework assignments make it less than ideal.

Ratings.comment: Professor Kim is a PhD student who has very long and meaningless lectures. Although there is a curve in this class, he does not post each exam grade until the end of the semester. In the syllabus, he claims that your grade on Carmen "does not matter" and is all based on "relative assessment." Try to avoid this TA as much as possible.

Mr. Kim is a PhD candidate and was kind, but I took int. macro with him and would not suggest it. Class wasn't difficult, but the lectures were not engaging/sparking discussion. Extra credit was given to make up for horrific midterm scores. An easy A in the end but constant mistakes on homeworks got old fast and email responses were infrequent

summary_comment: Professor Dempsey is passionate about his subject but struggles to effectively apply the concepts taught in his lectures to problem-solving, leading to difficulties on exams. Students find the class challenging and often rely on self-study. While some appreciate his energy and accessibility, others note his limited availability outside of office hours and his uneven pacing in lectures.

Ratings.comment: Much like the other reviews say, Dempsey is a nice guy and is passionate about what he teaches. However, he does not translate the conceptual style of his lectures into solving economic problems (i.e. those on his exams) very well at all. You are not taught how to actually apply the material to the things that matter. I don't recommend him.

This is a tough class. Dempsey does not write a lot of problems or give much practice material. He is not very accessible outside of class. During lecture, he spends too much time on simple concepts and speeds through the difficult material. You can learn enough to do well if you read the textbook and teach yourself.

I had Kyle Dempsey for ECON 4002.02 (Intermediate Macroeconomic Theory). The course consisted of one quiz, weekly problem sets, two midterm exams, and a final exam. The course was conducted online, and the midterm exams and final exam were proctored via Zoom. Prof. Dempsey was relatively unavailable outside of office hours. Doesn't allow appts.

I was highly impressed by Professor Dempsey especially since this was his first semester. He handled online classes extremely well and was always accessible. As for difficulty and grading, the top 15% of students received and A in my class. If you want to go to grad school for Econ, take Dempsey. He offers a true intro to real high level econ!

Solid guy. You can tell he's passionate about the course material and really cares about and wants his students to understand the material as well. Brings really good energy to his lectures and great about answering any questions students have.

summary_comment: Professor Chen is highly regarded by students for her knowledge and genuine interest in student learning, though her teaching style can be somewhat lecture-based. Despite this, her classes are engaging through discussions and offer substantial extra credit opportunities. Students find her approachable and recommend her class, noting its broad appeal across different majors and its practical, albeit sometimes challenging, content.

Ratings.comment: I really really like her. Taking the new course WGSST 2900. She is such a nice and warm and knowledgeable person. Strongly recommend.

This class was pretty easy and the extra credit on her exams made this an easy A. Professor Chen is knowledgeable and genuinely wants her students to learn. Her teaching can be quite boring as she reads from slides, but class discussion made it interesting.
The best professor on earth!

I thoroughly enjoyed this class! Dr. Chen is good about hearing both sides of an issue when debating solutions, and she offers a crazy amount of extra credit for exams. There are some calculations that can be tricky, but she goes over them in class and has the steps in her slides. Learned some really cool things in this class -would recommend!

Going to Dr. Chens class each week is like going to a conference where you get to learn a little bit about things you dont already know yet. The class was taken by a wide range of majors (like really wide) and she did a good job of making sure everyone understand the material and not just a specific major people. Grading for the class was easy.

Professor Chen uses an out-of date powerpoint system to preach neoliberal economic policies that have been all but rejected by the mainstream development community. Her assignments and exams rely on your memory of complex equations.

SEI.Subject: WGSST
SEI.Class Name: Women's Work? Sex, Race, Class & Labor

SEI.Subject: WGSST
SEI.Class Name: Topics in Women's, Gender and Sexuality Studies

summary_comment: Aubhik Khan is a highly intelligent and occasionally humorous professor, though his teaching style is often criticized for being disorganized and confusing. Students find his lectures repetitive and difficult to follow, and frequently need to correct him during class. Despite this, many appreciate the practical and insightful nature of his courses and find them rewarding once they grasp the material.

Ratings.comment: To be honest, he is the worst Professor I've ever seen. The concept of the ppt is very disarray, and he always need students to point out his mistakes. The most common thing he says is, "I don't know." If you want to get a good grade, just learn it by yourself. The assignment and quiz has nothing to do with the class content.

The only grades are the two midterms and the final. Honestly, this class was just so hard. If you didn't do well on one exam, it was just too hard to make it up. The teaching style was odd and he constantly had to have students correct him in lecture because his notes were wrong. Attendance is mandatory so make sure you go to class.

This guy really is a gem. He's hilariously blunt, but took a little to warm up to the class. He is really smart and can sometime come off as cocky, which he totally is. but also hes willing to admit when he messes up. Class isn't easy but very rewarding. If you don't understand something the first time, don't worry, he ll go over it at least 4x.

Aubhik Khan's class gives a glimpse into the real world of an economist and his classes were practical, funny and insightful for an intermediate econ course. Though his explanations can sometimes be confusing, a reading from textbook will reinforce the concepts better. the class gave a satisfaction of learning something new and cool every time.
