Ratings.comment: When people say a class is literally impossible to fail, they use literally wrong. However, only here is that not true. To pass the class you needed an overall of 35%. To get an A you needed 90% but an A- is 80%. But gets even easier, to get 100 on exams you only need to get 60%. Every single person got at least a B-, and every one I knew got an A

summary_comment: This professor is highly regarded for his effective teaching methods, making economics both fun and accessible through simple explanations and engaging lectures. He assigns minimal, extra-credit homework and easy, open-book pop quizzes, ensuring students can perform well with consistent effort. Additionally, he is responsive and enthusiastic, ensuring students fully understand the material and feel supported throughout the course.

Ratings.comment: All homework is extra credit and is just based off of completion plus short papers that boosted me 6 percentage points at the end.  10 pop quizzes drop the lowest one but they're open book and just based on the day's lecture so they guaranteed 4/5 basically.  He pretty much makes econ as fun and simple as possible.  All multiple choice everything.
Tony is a great professor and makes sure the student understands the material covered. He responds to email right away and is always excited to teach

summary_comment: The professor is knowledgeable but struggles with organization and clarity, making the class challenging and largely unhelpful for econ majors. Exams are difficult and not well-aligned with in-class material, while lectures, though initially understandable, do not adequately prepare students for assessments.

Ratings.comment: This class was extremely hard and I did not learn barely anything by the end of the semester. If at all possible, take another prof for this course. Especially if you are majoring in Econ. It will not help you any to take him. He explains concepts in class and makes them seem very understandable, but then exams are very difficult.
This class was very tough, and very little practice problems were given to help study.

Not a confident lecturer, often makes mistakes or stares at the board checking his work. Not good at explaining things, I took macroecon at the same time and learned more micro there. His homework is kind of hard because the problems aren't similar to whats done in class, but his tests are just the homework problems with different number.
He knows a lot about econ, but the class was disorganized and the grading did not seem fair.

summary_comment: This professor is generally well-regarded as a nice and helpful individual who is willing to assist students. However, his accent can make understanding him challenging, and some students recommend sitting near the front and seeking additional tutoring. His classes are manageable, with homework questions often available online and test questions frequently derived from homework and pop quizzes. Students note that while the material is straightforward, the grading can be tough, with a significant portion of the grade coming from short-answer tests.

Ratings.comment: Super nice guy. Homework questions can be found online word for word. Gives easy pop quizzes as extra credit. Tests are all short answer, but many questions are taken from homework and pop quizzes. Very manageable class.

I couldn't understand him because of accent and the classroom was loud because of the A/C system in the room.  So make sure you sit up front, be prepared to spend a lot of time getting tutored (at Arps hall), and use the study suggestions listed in the book.  Like the online study material.

He is a really nice person and very willing to help. His accent can be a little hard to understand but all the material is in the book anyway. Homework questions could be found online and the exam questions sometimes came from the homework questions. I found him really easy, but a great professor overall.

He's a nice guy, but hard to understand at times. The homework problems and answers can be found online word for word. His curve was set up so a 55% was a B, so he grades pretty tough. His tests are short answer and worth 80% of the grade.  He lectures pretty much the whole time, so don't expect to get out early.

summary_comment: This professor is highly regarded for his helpfulness and knowledge, with a generous curve that makes it difficult to fail. However, his lectures can be challenging and dry, and some find them hard to follow without additional support like attending office hours. Despite the learning curve, students appreciate his willingness to assist during office hours and find the exams relatively easy if they put in the effort to study.

Ratings.comment: He is a great teacher, helpful and knowledgeable. There is a curve for everything so it's really hard to fail this class. The material is hard, because it's all about statistics, if you are good at that, then you are guaranteed an A!!! The first half of the class is basically a review of stats. Very easy. I hardly study and got an A on the exam.

Hard to understand sometimes, makes up words (like "shiftment"), teaches straight from the slides out of the book, class isn't mandatory, but he gives you .1% extra credit for each you attend (up to 2%). Most people just sign the sheet he passes around and leaves. Generous built in curve on exams. Class is dry as can be.

Kind of hard to understand and sometimes unclear, but if you go to office hours, he answers all your questions wonderfully. His exams are pretty easy too so long as you study. If you want a great lecturer, this is not your guy, but if you're willing to go to office hours, you'll learn a lot. He very genuinely wants to help!

summary_comment: The professor is highly regarded for her easy-to-follow class structure and willingness to curve grades when necessary, making her a very approachable and kind instructor who provides good examples and a well-organized course. However, some students find her lectures challenging to follow due to her limited English proficiency, despite her extensive knowledge of the subject matter.

Ratings.comment: Very easy class. Read the book and you will do well on her midterms and quizzes. Curves the class if needed. Very nice teacher.
It was well structured class.She gave good examples. She was nice and kind.
She was kind and helpful.The course was well structured.

She's very knowledgably on all of the topics that she discusses but unfortunately it?s very hard to understand what she is saying. Also, because she can't speak English so well it's hard to get help from her although she is very willing.

summary_comment: This professor is considered challenging with a strong emphasis on self-study, as students must read the entire textbook post-class and often find his lectures hard to follow due to his accent and slide-based presentations. Exams are known to be difficult, though he provides a significant curve, particularly for the final exam. While some find the course painful and deadening, others appreciate the study guide and acknowledge its helpfulness.

Ratings.comment: Not a good teacher, you couldn't understand what he is talking about at all, and the exams are hard!

Anybody that recommended him is irresponsible. Only 7% got A (<10 people). Not bad, but he's really not for teaching. Very strong accent and just reading through slides in lectures. You Need read the whole textbook after class by yourself, which yet can't guarantee you a decent grade. No bonus questions in any exams. painless but deadful course..A-

Not a Bad Teacher. Very Challenging class, but the study guide was very helpful. The midterms weren't that bad, but the final was very difficult. He did give a huuge curve. I had an 85% and got a solid A.

summary_comment: This professor is highly regarded for his clarity and willingness to help, making lectures accessible with clear explanations. However, some students found his grading inconsistent and the class occasionally boring. Despite these challenges, many still consider him an effective teacher who provides valuable resources and makes high grades achievable with consistent effort.

Ratings.comment: One of the best teachers I’ve had so far. He was always glad to answer questions and provided helpful examples in class.

very harsh, inconsistent grader!! very boring lecturer. the REQUIRED text wasn't published until halfway through the quarter, and then one of the questions on the final was to fill in the page number of a quote. otherwise, didn't ask specific questions. if you ramble a lot and write everything you're thinking, you'll probably write what he wants.

At first he seemed more repetative than needed, but once we got to the tougher stuff that tendancy came in handy. -- By the way, the final was worth 15% because it covered only the last week of class. The homework wasn't a cinch, but if listened to his examples, it was by no means difficult. An A is very attainable.
He is very clear in his explanation , read the book before go to the class . He is a great teacher !

Nice guy.  Provides very helpful packet of lecture notes.  If you come to class and follow the notes, you could skip the book.  OTOH if you skip class, you can get what you need from the book as long as you understand it all on your own.

summary_comment: Professor Arora is highly regarded for his passion and dedication to teaching, making complex economic concepts engaging and relevant. Students find him supportive and encouraging, though some note that the curriculum could benefit from more comprehensive coverage due to frequent absences and review sessions. His ability to connect course material with real-world examples enhances learning, leading many to seek out his other classes.

Ratings.comment: He loves teaching and really wants you to do well. One of my favorite classes in college. Go to class and get to know him.

Very helpful professor.  He really encourages class participation and wants everyone in the class to do well.  I am not interested in History but he made this class worth the time.  Only issue was limited amount of information he taught, between vacation and review classes we could have covered twice the amount of content.  Great professor though.

Dr. Arora is an excellent teacher. He relates the course material to easily relatable ideas and events. This is an interesting subject - for those interested in economic dev. - but Dr. Arora makes the material go from numbers on a page (the text) to interesting stories about the history of the world. I will look to take other classes he teaches.

Professor Arora does a nice of making economic content interesting and encourages students to understand concepts and cross-country comparisons as opposed to strictly factual data. However, the tests are then almost all based on PowerPoint memorization. Cognitive dissonance! It's not too hard if you're good at... memorizing, I guess.

summary_comment: The professor explains concepts clearly and relates them to real-life economic stories, making her class engaging and helpful for students considering economics as a major. However, another student found her lectures rushed and difficult to follow due to her English proficiency and lack of organization, suggesting self-study from the textbook was necessary. A third student highly recommends her, praising clear explanations and extra credit opportunities, but notes that consistent attendance and studying are crucial for success.

Ratings.comment: Explain questions very clear. She also talked some economic interesting stories that related to our life. For homework you can go to her office hour to ask her. The exam is easy if you pay attention to her class. She is very helpful and because of her class, i changed my major to economic. Take her class!!
Rushes through nearly every lecture. Doesn't speak English very well and isn't very organized. I had to learn everything from the book.
Great professor. Explains everything really clearly and is willing to answer questions in class. Gives extra credit quizzes. Go to class and read the book and you'll be golden.

summary_comment: Professor Baack is a knowledgeable and engaging lecturer, particularly for those interested in economic history, though his teaching style requires students to rely heavily on in-class notes and active participation. His exams are essay-based and graded rigorously, often leading to a challenging grading curve. While some students find his classes interesting and well-organized, others struggle with the lack of supplementary materials and harsh grading standards.

Ratings.comment: there are no slides notes exam reviews. wants us to write word by word.  AVOID.  harsh grader.

There are no online notes, study guides, presentations, review sessions or additional material. He grades the essays quite harshly and provides no feedback whatsoever. With only a midterm and a final, this can be detrimental to your grade.
he don't have any notes and ppt during the class. you should take notes just by listening.. and he grades the essays so strictly. His class is almost B average or lower...

Professor Baack is an awesome teacher who really enjoys the subject matter that he is teaching and communicates it very clearly to students.  I would highly recommend him to anyone interested in economic history (i.e ECON 515 and 516).  Don't need a textbook, but have to go to lecture (or borrow someone's notes) to get the material.

First of all, you must go to class for this. He doesn't use powerpoints so you can only get notes based off of lectures. However, I thought was a great professor. Lectures were clear and organized and the exams were 5 essay question options, you pick 3. Based on my notes, I thought the exams were pretty easy. Don't get the book, never used it once
Wise man, however as a professor he doesn't give his students a base to go off of for exams. Broad subject matter, no homework or quizzes
Lots of work, but a really interesting class. Great teacher.

Don't buy book. Lectures organized half of the time, other half very hard to follow. Grades exams really tough. Class graded on a curve. Hard GEC. Not a lot of work during the quarter, but a lot of cramming before midterm and final (only two grades). I have heard there are easier profs teaching 515 so try and take them first.

Just don't take Econ 530 with Baack, not if you are remotely interested in the subject and don't want to be majorly turned off. He may be smart, but he also inserts his politics into his teaching, doesn't show up to his own office hours, and makes class extremely difficult to follow. I regret taking this class with him.

Really interesting professor, if you're slightly interested in economic history, the class will not be boring...everything on exams comes from his lectures so you don't need the book. But make sure to pay attention and write good notes in class because the exams are fairly thorough.

Very knowledgeable about what he's teaching. Materials are somewhat challenging and everything on exam comes from lecture so you will have to go to class and take notes. Lectures can be boring at times but overall you will learn a lot, especially if you're into the subject. Overall I recommend Prof. Baack.

His midterm and final are essay based and come straight from the material in lecture "second verse same as the first" He is a funny guy and extremely helpful. You dont need the book to which is a plus.

Baack is one of those professors to take if you are interested in the material. He has so many interesting things to say. The exams are drawn directly from lecture material so make sure you show up, they are also sort of difficult. There was a substantial (15-20pg) term paper for this course as well. Nothing but good things to say about Baack.
He is passionate and a historian. Great topics. Pay attention since exams include much of what is lectured. Good teacher.
Really interesting course.  Your dead if you don't go to class though.  Exams focus more on what's covered in class not what's in the book.

Baack is a great teacher and a fantastic guy (toot toot toot)! He knows his stuff and is willing to help. However, 530 is super boring, he lectures with no slides, and exams are 100% of the grade. Study hard, go to every lecture, and you should be fine. Take him if you get a chance!

Seems easy, but exam is graded really tough. Fun class, lots of stories. Took the 515 class as a freshman though. Might be easier for upperclassman. Fun guy, but be sure to be VERY THROUGH on the exam (as it is the only thing he grades on).
He is a great teacher and storyteller.  Pay close attention and take notes in class and you will be fine.  He has a great sense of humor and it was a pleasure to be in his class.
very interesting lecture, all essay tests with multipul propmpts to choose from.  He has been my favorite Prof. in the ECON department.
Pretty funny guy, class is easy if you go and take notes

Highly recommended. The material was easy to understand. I went to just about all the lectures and probably did less than 10% of the reading and still got a B+. Lectures aren't boring (even for an Econ course), so I would attend as many as possible.

good lecturer. will let you out early every class. doesn't use a lot of visual aids but if you listen and take good notes an A in this class is not a problem. Little work during the quarter only a midterm and final both short essay. knows a lot about the subject and tells funny stories.
test questions are tricky
good lecturer. Of course there are moments when you  may fall asleep due to boredom, but that happens in all classes. His little stories are amusing...tests aren't that bad.
I don not understand the reviews.  Baack's Econ 515 lecture was one of the most interesting I've taken at OSU.  Other people in the class seemed to agree as well...
Very boring. No powerpoints, just lectures. Write very fast. Didn't feel the tests were a very accurate representation of class
By far the most boring class I have taken.  The class is a joke...final is 50% of grade.
Some what interesting class but can be very boring.  Only lectures with few visual aids or handouts.  Midterm multi-choice questions are very tricky.
great lectures, very helpful, very interesting guy once you talk to him out of class
Easy going, boring lectures.  Material was tough but he's willing to help if you ask

Solid lecturer, if a bit slow/boring sometimes. Tells some interesting stories, sometimes. Basically, if you come to class and understand the material (feel free to ask questions), then the tests will not be very hard. My class was small, and this guy seems better suited to teach a large lecture...if that tells you anything. But it was a fine GEC.
Excellent lecturer! Does not take well to questions though, so just enjoy the stories and read the book.
Excellent teacher. Try to get him all you can.
Great teacher, tells lots of good stories.

Great teacher! Old fashioned, meaning no PowerPoints, or computer aides. Straight lecture which requires a lot of attention. Tests are challenging, but fair. Tells great stories and is a good teacher!

If you like teachers that get up and lecture for 2 hours without anything to look at (powerpoints, handouts, etc.), take him.  I dont agree with the others at all but I guess they must really love econ classes
He was very interesting, and really knew the material. He was able to present lots of alternatives for situations. Overall, i enjoyed this class. Study hard for tests, they're the whole grade
Good prof. Knows his stuff.
Great prof, great class
I thought that he was a great prof.  He explained many issues that are going on today.  I extremely enjoyed this class.

Interesting lectures.  You will learn some very cool economic arguments dealing with the rise and fall of feudalsim, the causes & consequences of slavery, the true motivation behind the American Revolution, & possible causes of the Industrial Revolution.
Great prof, excellent class.

He is clear and presents different and opposing views. Ne knows the subject well. He reviews the material from the previous class, if you don't get it first time you will get it next time so I hardly needed to study except a short review before the exam
No Comments
No Comments
simply put, the man
interesting teacher
lucid and interesting lectures

summary_comment: Kevin is an effective instructor who makes the subject matter accessible, even for those who find economics challenging. His classes are generally fair and straightforward, with grades based on easy homework and curved exams, though the exams themselves are known to be quite difficult. Students appreciate his willingness to help and find his lectures informative, though some find them somewhat dry.

Ratings.comment: I hate economics but Kevin's class made it bearable. He teaches straight from slides so its kinda boring. Your grade is based off easy homework problems and exams. The exams are fairly hard, but he curves the exams. Studying a little from the book helps. Take him if you can
Class was very interesting. Kevin exposed a wide variety of economic issues concerning the country today, some I knew nothing about. Would recommend Kevin for a professor anytime.

Fairly easy class. He puts up slides from class on Carmen, but leaves some parts out but you can find them on the book publisher's website. Exams based on textbook. Went to about 50% of lectures and got an A.
The class is not easy. Exams are tough. To get a good grade you have to read the text book very well. The teacher is a nice guy though, willing to help.

summary_comment: The professor is highly regarded for his thorough explanations and availability during office hours, making him an effective teacher who rewards hard work with good grades. While the course material is challenging, the exams are curved, providing some relief. One student even considers him the best teacher they have ever had at OSU, praising his dedication and willingness to assist students in achieving high grades.

Ratings.comment: Make sure you attend class, especially before midterms and finals because he goes over example problems right before them. He explains things very thoroughly if you attend his office hours. He is also very nice and approachable. You will work, but he will reward you with good grades for your efforts!
He is a great guy, knows the material well, but the class was tough. He is very helpful and will go out of his way to help you. Exams are not easy, but the curve helps.

This TA alone is the best teacher i've ever had at OSU. You can truely tell that he loves teaching and will do anything for you to get a great grade in Econ 520. I wish all my professors and TA's had the attitude like him!!!!!!!!
No Comments

summary_comment: The professor was effective but challenging, covering material quickly and requiring extensive study for exams. Despite the difficulty, she provided significant support and assistance to her students.

Ratings.comment: She was an ok techer, and she tried, but it was still really hard. Went through classes super fast, and was hard to kept up. Exams were ok, but had to study for days.
Very helpful

summary_comment: This professor is highly regarded for his effective teaching methods and dedication to student success. He excels at making complex economic concepts engaging and accessible, and his leniency with grading is appreciated. Students consistently recommend his classes due to his thorough explanations and enthusiastic approach to teaching.

Ratings.comment: Very nice guy. Knows how to teach the subject well. Always goes out of his way to help his students. Very lenient when it comes to grades. Economics is a dry subject but he does his best to make it interesting. Highly recommended!

He is a great teacher, take him if you can. he give tons of examples and the quizzes are pretty easy. he also give bonus points for coming to class. all and all this class isnt bad, i thought he was good, i got an a.
An excellent instructor. The class was really fun and very interesting.
Great teacher. Make sure to take his classes if you can.
No Comments

Thought that he did a very good job explaining the material, he did not just read off of the slides, he did many drawlings on the bored, was enthused about teaching. Spoke english very well. All in all, a very good experience
Decent TA to have, good job in making materials organized and understandable. Lecture is boring though, so I go to recitation more often than attending the lecture.

summary_comment: Doodlebob is highly regarded as an excellent and easy professor who keeps classes engaging and offers substantial extra credit for attendance. He emphasizes the importance of understanding the material, particularly for the final exam, which counts for 50% of the grade. Students consistently praise his relaxed teaching style, sense of humor, and willingness to help students succeed.

Ratings.comment: doodlebob.
This guy is the man. He is a great professor and really easy. He gives extra credit just for going to class. Hes funny and keeps it interesting. Take with him
good!!!!

This prof is joking. Only fair number of people pass this course. He gives us extra credits, but make sure to go to class. The final is 50% of your whole grade, and it's accumulative. It's important to understand the materials perfectly otherwise, it will be very tricky.

This class is pretty easy and definitely a GPA booster. Just need to know very basic algebra & intro level econ to get an A. The Mid-term was a joke since most questions come from either HW assignments or practice problems. Plus, there are tons of opportunities to earn extra points. Yasin is so awesome. Highly recommended teacher.

Great class. Take his advice and bring markers. He is interested in the subject and wishes to convey the info. The HW helps and the notes are invaluable. Look at the lecture slides and you will be fine. Good class for globalization majors.

Yasin is great, I like his relaxed teaching style and tests that are designed off h/w material and questions that you can study beforehand. Class was curved and he gave another 7% extra credit. Don't buy the book, just go to lectures and take notes.

Greatest class I have taken at OSU simply because Yasin is constantly joking around. One time it was cold outside and he walked into class and asked us if we wanted to go home due to the cold (and drink hot chocolate). Material is easy and Yacin knows his stuff. He is helpful and wants to see everyone succeed...unlike many other professors at OSU

He's cool and relatable, and can't be more than 26.  I'm pretty sure he's a stoner, but that was right up my alley. It also makes for some interesting class discussions such as supply and demand in a weed market and comparing the rates between the countries of Narnia and The Matrix.

summary_comment: The professor is consistently reliable and competent, delivering a balanced and effective teaching experience that meets expectations without standing out as particularly exceptional or deficient. The course material is well-covered, and while the lectures maintain a steady pace, they neither overly challenge nor bore the students.

Ratings.comment: Perfectly adequate in every possible way. Not too easy or hard, too compelling or too boring. Just completely average, not that that's a bad thing. Will get the job done.

summary_comment: Rob is an effective teacher who presents material clearly and offers fair, straightforward tests, making the class accessible and not overly challenging. He is highly approachable and willing to provide additional support when needed, and students find him both knowledgeable and personable.

Ratings.comment: Rob presents material well and tests are very fair and straightforward.  This was not a difficult class at all.  Plus, Rob is a generally awesome guy.

Rob presents the material well, but he does not give a lot of examples unless you ask him to. He is very willing to help if you need it. We had 2 exams and a group research project as our only grads. I highly recommend.
Very good teacher, very willing to help out and just an all around nice guy.

summary_comment: The professor is generally regarded as knowledgeable and thorough, providing detailed notes and practice exams that help students prepare for tests. However, the class can be quite demanding in terms of note-taking and memorization, and some find it monotonous despite the professor's attempts to make the material engaging.

Ratings.comment: Not too bad. He gives out practice exams for you to study, if you can do those pretty well you shouldn't have a problem. Only downside is the large amount of note-taking and amount of info you havee to remember.
Very hard class. Writes all of his notes by hand, doesn't know what Carmen is. Good luck.

This class is terribly boring. He stands up there writing on the board the whole time, then right before the exam he gives you a study guide with "sample questions" that may as well be the exam. I don't want to complain but why did I listen to him ramble for 10 hours to be handed answers? I liked him but the class is pointless.
He was pretty good, lots of notes and the tests seemed to come strait from the notes.
No Comments
No Comments
Great guy. very funny and interesting. Class material a little boring but he makes it fun. One of my better econ classes here.
Very boring classes, but Kaboski is a good professor.

Teaches fairly well. The material is a bit dry in my opinion. Should not be difficult (assuming you attend somewhat regularly and/or read the text comprehensively) to recieve an A or A- in the course.
This guy told the class if he knows your name he won't fail you.  I went to two classes and got a B-.  He is a cake walk.

summary_comment: This professor is widely regarded as ineffective, failing to provide clear or useful content during lectures and instead relying on random quizzes to ensure attendance. Students find his lectures confusing and describe him as unapproachable, advising others to avoid his class if possible.

Ratings.comment: This teacher sucks. He does not have any idea what he is talking about. He gives random quizzes so you have to go to class. Tries to be cool but fails in that regard

attendence in mandatory because once a week he gives pop quizzes. he never uses power point or any other notes and just blabs on in class. sooo confusing and kind of a jerk. if you can avoid it, don't take his class

summary_comment: Kraybill is an knowledgeable and passionate professor who effectively conveys complex material, making his class both challenging and engaging. However, some students find his grading standards stringent and his teaching style occasionally dry, particularly without clear connections to course readings. Overall, he is considered helpful and interesting, though improvements could be made in aligning assessments with course content.

Ratings.comment: He really knows his stuff! He is so passionate about what he is teaching. Even though the material itself can be heavy at times, I really did appreciate him as a prof. He is great if you go to office hours and such an interesting guy. Personally, I would take his class. He has lots of cool anecdotes from when he lived in Cong!

532 is a very intersting class, but Kraybill made it so hard for student tolearn and pass his class which is not a requirement for most students who take it. He is extremely stingy on grades and he is boring as a professor.

A very good professor who grades fair. If I would change anything, it would be that much of the textbook reading assignments were not reflected in the mid-term and final. Still, a very helpful and interested prof.

summary_comment: The professor is known for making the class relatively easy, provided students attend lectures and study the notes, with minimal homework and straightforward tests. However, opinions vary; some find his lectures unengaging and the material challenging without a solid algebra background, while others appreciate his humor and organization, finding the class enjoyable and recommending it despite its difficulty level for some.

Ratings.comment: Not a hard class, regardless of who's teaching it.  If you GO to class and study the notes you'll get a good grade.  Much of the material requires a little knowledge of algebra.  If you suck at adding and subtracting variables, this class is not for you.

The class was very easy. Only 4 homeworks the whole quarter, 2 midterms, and a final with plenty of extra credit opportunities. As long as you pay attention and take notes, the tests are super easy. I did not put much effort into the class and got an easy A. I would recommend this class.

Not the best lecturer by far and definately does nothing to spice up this dull as dirt class. Slides are poorly organized and not very detailed and he seems to focus on wierd stuff. Homework is time consuming but tests are multiple choice. Overall grade: C.

Mike was a good teacher.  He had a predictable, organized layout: lectures each class, papers due bi-weekly, a mditerm, and a final.  The tests were somewhat challenging and did require you to apply your knowledge a little further than you may have expected.  But he is not the toughest grader with papers.  He is humorous and helpful.  Recommended.
Plz...Do not take this clas. It's horrible. He does not know anything. He is just guessing. That's it. There are some great second writing classes like 367.01 and so on.

Mike was a great instructor for being a graduate student.  He has a subtle sense of humor and makes class time enjoyable.  Even though it's a writing class, there's not as much writing as you'd expect.  The topics we discussed were well chosen.  There were 5 writing assignments (about 1,000 words each), 2 exams, and a presentation. Recommended!

summary_comment: This professor is not recommended for students seeking an easy grade. While she is described as helpful outside of class, her lectures are considered boring and unclear, often confusing even herself. Tests are particularly challenging and not well-explained. Students generally advise taking the course with a different instructor if possible.

Ratings.comment: Not an easy A. She is boring to listen to talk but a nice teacher. Trying will get you a B otherwise good luck. Take 520 with someone else dont take this with her. Her tests are not clear and she confuses herself more than 1/2 of the time and has to restart her lecture. Extremely UNCLEAR! Glad its over!
I would not recomend this class to anyone. The prof was not clear. She was helpful, so I would go to her after class hours but that did not help.
No Comments

summary_comment: The professor struggles significantly with clarity and explanation, making the class difficult to follow, especially due to a noticeable accent. Students generally recommend relying on the textbook and supplementary materials rather than attending lectures, and warn that tests are challenging and not well-explained by the instructor. Overall, the class is seen as subpar with limited value from in-person instruction.

Ratings.comment: This class has real potential to be interesting and useful but teacher makes the class a drag. An obvious but not overwhelming accent can be distracting. Her language barrier makes it hard for her to explain the information in an understandable way. Better off just reading the book. Recommend getting the study guide if you don't want to read a ton.
Responsible.

she has trouble explaining hard concepts and not a good teacher. I would recommend this class only if you prefer learning right out of the book instead of attending lecture.I only went to 4 lectures and got an A but I did have to put alot of time into studying. tests were all tricky MC ?'s, but there was a fat curve.read text and study lec.notes!

She is a really poor instructor. I would advise someone to not take this class with her. I actually enjoy learning this material, but her tests and homework were ridiculous. The average on the final was a D. The tests were VERY hard and she is not very helpful. Hard to understand, confusion questions on test, AWFUL class with her.

Do Not Take this class with her!! She is the worst lecturer I have ever had. You are basically alone with your book and you'd might as well memorize the whole thing because she is not clear on what you need to know. Take my advice, save yourself. I e-mailed with my concerns and she basically said "Tough". Wow, bad prof.

Prof Zhang is a decent prof. for 520. It's only necessary to go to class to give HW assignments in and get practice exams for the midterms and final. She's hard to understand b/c of her accent, but her notes are online, and she gives an extra credit assignment. HW is not too bad, and final grades are curved, to make things fair for everyone.

summary_comment: The professor is generally difficult to understand and struggles with basic communication, which makes clear explanations challenging. Students find his lectures hard to follow and rely heavily on attending classes and studying the book to perform well on tests and quizzes. Despite some positive feedback regarding his helpfulness and fair grading, the overall consensus is that his teaching quality is subpar.

Ratings.comment: Hard to understand. He doesn't know basic words, and has a hard time saying numbers?? He can't really explain anything clearly.  Seems like you need to go to lecture to pass tests, but lectures are hard to understand? Has pop quizzes throughout so you have to go to class to makes sure you don't miss them. Would not recommend.

Not as bad as most people say. He's hard to understand, but he grades easy, and the slides are all on Carmen. He doesn't teach anything that isn't in the book, so as long as you read it, you'll do fine.
He is not that good of a teacher.  He often makes mistakes when giving examples.  He does not curve the course despite low averages.  I would not recommend him unless you excel in economics.
He is very difficult to understand and often misspells and misinterprets English words (he's Korean). If you like teaching yourself with a textbook, this is the professor for you.
difficult to understand in class.  the subject was easy and getting an A wasn't a problem, but my grade was more closely attributed to the book rather than the actual class.

Amazing..very helpful & understanding...keeps pace with the class..fair grading & prepares the class for each quiz & midterm & nearly discussing all the questions to be tested on the exam!!!..highly recommended to get a min grade of B-

summary_comment: Professor Klaiber is highly regarded for his depth of knowledge and passion in economics, making the subject engaging and easy to understand. His lectures closely align with test material, with many questions directly derived from quizzes, making the exams manageable once students grasp the initial concepts. Students find him approachable and helpful both inside and outside the classroom, providing thorough study guides and clear explanations.

Ratings.comment: Professor Klaiber is an in-depth lecturer who is very knowledgeable and passionate in economics. Hes extremely nice and understanding outside of class. Tests are based heavily lecture material and some questions are taken straight from the quizzes.

This class was fine. It was required for my major and wasn't too bad. 3 exams and a lot of the questions are recycled from old quizzes, so they're pretty doable and after the first one you really know what to expect. 6 HW assignments (100 points??) & open note unlimited attempt weekly quizzes. All in all, not particularly fun but not too bad.

Dr. Klaiber is a super nice, pleasant guy and a really good professor. He really simplified everything and made it easy to understand. He would always make sure everyone was on the same page before moving on. Most econ classes make me fall asleep but his was actually pretty interesting.

Great Professor, Clear and concise in lecture. Theres only i believe 6 homeworks and the rest is the exams. He gives great Study guides and a review. Super helpful, i learned a lot in this class he was very clear with the material, explained everything well.

summary_comment: This professor is highly regarded for his engaging and insightful teaching style, encouraging critical thinking and real-world application of economic concepts. Students appreciate his availability during office hours and his dedication to helping them succeed. While the material is challenging, particularly through problem sets and case analyses, the course is considered one of the most valuable academic experiences, with grades being highly curved.

Ratings.comment: Lectures are a must, as he doesn't record. Requires participation for "x" amount of lectures. Available at office hours. Do and understand the problem sets, and understand the case studies, and you'll be fine. Great guy! Graded on 3 exams, no homework/projects.

He is an amazing professor! He is caring, always encourage us to think harder and participate, insightful, very smart, and respectful. He expects his students to think critically and applies the economic knowledge into the real world cases. The problem sets are very helpful for understanding the knowledge better. I learned a lot from the class!

Easily one of the best professors I've had in my time at Ohio State. Professor clearly wanted his students to succeed and did an excellent job keeping class engaging and communicating learning objectives. 10/10
Very genuine and well organized.

I graduated with this class. Javier is always available to discuss during office hours. Through the cases I learned how to read articles critically and learned real world economics. Best class I took at OSU!!
Hard material covered. Test is highly based on problem set and case analysis. Grade is highly curved. Professor Donna is a very nice guy who willing to help everyone. Go to class.
Best class in the second year of the Ph.D. so far. Javier is really insightful and honest.

This is the class where I learned the most in OSU. Exams are difficult. The grade is curved. Javier is very open to answer questions and meet with you during office hours. Awesome class!! And by the way, I got an A!!

Javier is very passionate about IO, market power and the structure of markets. Some of the topics in the class may seem arid, but Javier puts a lot of effort motivating them with real-world cases, discussing antitrust cases and explaining why it is important. The exams are somewhat hard, but he is very fair grading. I strongly recommend this class.

Very good class. Professor Donna divides the lectures between theory and a real-world case analysis. He discusses the cases with the students in class. It's very interactive and fun. It's like a business school class. I learned a lot. Finally an econ class with real applications! Thanks for a great Fall semester.
Professor Donna's classes are intellectually inspiring. Each class he discusses a case with us where we applied the theory to a real-world case.  I found this strategy genuinely enjoyable.

Professor Donna is easily one of the best professors I have had at Ohio State. He encouraged students to think for themselves and defend what they think. He not only did this through homework and test, but also through every lecture he gave.

Great class for Econ majors! He's Argentine, but honestly I found his accent was perfectly fine and comprehensible. His class is good to fill in the gaps from Intermediate Micro, which in my opinion is pretty poorly taught, at least the BS version
Problem Sets take a long time to complete, but he allows people to work in groups (up to 4 students).  He pulls from the problem sets for the exams and has a very generous curve!!

Overall good but hard class. It is really hard to understand him (he has a South American accent) which makes it absurdly easy to zone out. However, he will meet with you and help you whenever you need it and he curves a lot. Takes exam material straight out of the homework (but they are still hard)
Very hard class. At the beginning I thought about dropping it but I stuck with it. At the end I learned a lot. goood experience overall

The class is very hard. Problem sets are long and hard. Two midterms, very hard as well. I have difficulties to adapt during the first part. After the 1st midterm I started to study more. I did the catch up and an A- in the end (grade is curved). I learned a lot, specially about market structure and game theory. I invested a lot of time too.

The class is very challenging. At the beginning was extremely difficult for me. I did poor in my first midterm. Then I started to attend class regularly and do the problem sets. I ended up with A-. I learned a lot. But also studied a lot. Grade is curved.

Difficult class for me at beginning as an international student, his spanish accent and usage of ppt distracted my attention. My first midterm sucked. But, he changed his method, choosing to use blackboard. I found that was very helpful. Grade is curved. So don't worry about that. It's his first term at osu and he is a phD from Northwestern.

Stands at the board and teaches directly from the book. Luckily, lectures are not mandatory. Problem sets are difficult but you can work in groups and the class is curved anyway. Tests are somewhat difficult, so make sure to study. Gives enough extra credit assignments to make it easy to get a good grade if you try. Not a fun class, but manageable.
The grade is curved, but his exams are extremely hard. He knows what his talking about, but he lacks clarity. I would rather read the book than go to lecture. I wouldn't recommend his class.
tough class but extremely sharp professor. if you really want to get deep into economics, get in here.
